natural resilience."<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=author |first=Matt BellMatt Bell is the |last2=Recently |first2=Most |last3=of “Appleseed” |last4=Write |first4=“Refuse to Be Done: How to |last5=Drafts.” |first5=Rewrite a Novel in Three |date=2025-03-01 |title=An Island Family Faces Rising Waters and an Unexpected Guest |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/01/books/review/charlotte-mcconaghy-wild-dark-shore.html |access-date=2026-02-06 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
The novel received positive reviews from critics.<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://www.bookreporter.com/reviews/wild-dark-shore |title=Wild Dark Shore {{!}} Bookreporter.com |language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news |date=2025-03-07 |title=Review {{!}} ‘Wild Dark Shore’ is a captivating novel set in a very remote place |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2025/03/06/wild-dark-shore-charlotte-mcconaghy-review/ |archive-url=http://web.archive.org/web/20250313142818/https://www.washingtonpost.com/books/2025/03/06/wild-dark-shore-charlotte-mcconaghy-review/ |archive-date=2025-03-13 |access-date=2026-02-06 |work=The Washington Post |language=en}}</ref> Leah Rachel von Essen of the [[Chicago Review of Books]] wrote that "an exceptional book that hands readers a bittersweet helping of sorrow and joy, sounding a clarifying call towards a symbiotic survival that prioritizes our need to do more than simply subsist: to put trust in each other and in the nature that surrounds us."<ref>{{Cite web |last=Essen |first=Leah Rachel von |date=2025-03-05 |title=Surviving Disaster in "Wild Dark Shore" |url=https://chireviewofbooks.com/2025/03/05/wild-dark-shore/ |access-date=2026-02-06 |website=Chicago Review of Books |language=en-US}}</ref> It received a [[starred review]] from [[Kirkus Reviews]].<ref>{{Cite book |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/charlotte-mcconaghy/wild-dark-shore/ |title=WILD DARK SHORE {{!}} Kirkus Reviews |language=en}}</ref> Matt Bell of the [[The New York Times|New York Times]] wrote that the novel "abounds with evocative nature writing, including precocious Orly's moving monologues about the dandelion, the buzzy burr, the dinosaur tree and other model specimens of natural resilience."<ref name=":0">{{Cite news |last=author |first=Matt BellMatt Bell is the |last2=Recently |first2=Most |last3=of “Appleseed” |last4=Write |first4=“Refuse to Be Done: How to |last5=Drafts.” |first5=Rewrite a Novel in Three |date=2025-03-01 |title=An Island Family Faces Rising Waters and an Unexpected Guest |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2025/03/01/books/review/charlotte-mcconaghy-wild-dark-shore.html |access-date=2026-02-06 |work=The New York Times |language=en-US |issn=0362-4331}}</ref>

Publishers Weekly gave the book a more review, writing that "McConaghy ratchets up the tension as the characters’ paranoia and mutual suspicion increases and their motives are revealed, though she scuttles the momentum with predictable romantic subplots, and a late-stage plot twist strains credulity. For the most part, though, McConaghy blends entertainment with a sobering message about conservation and the impacts of geographic isolation."<ref>{{Cite web |date=Invalid date |title=Wild Dark Shore by Charlotte McConaghy |url=https://www.publishersweekly.com/9781250827951 |access-date=2026-02-06 |website=www.publishersweekly.com}}</ref>

[[File:Old_map-Austin-1873-sm.jpg|thumb|"Bird's Eye View of the City of Austin", an 1873 map of Austin. Note that College Street (now 12th Street) can be seen extending from the center of the Texas State Capitol building up into Robertson Hill. College Street and Congress Avenue appear to be the two main streets of Austin, centering upon the State Capitol Building.]]The '''Southgate–Lewis House''' is a historic landmark located approximately a mile east of the [[Texas State Capitol]] in [[Austin, Texas]]. It is situated in Six Square, an [[African Americans|African American]] cultural heritage district.<ref>{{Cite web|last=The City of Austin.|title=African American Cultural and Heritage Facility.|url=https://www.austintexas.gov/aachf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=City of Austin.|title=Guide to Six Square: Austin's African American Cultural Heritage District.|date=7 January 2022 |url=https://www.austintexas.org/austin-insider-blog/post/six-square-african-american-cultural-heritage-district/}}</ref> The Southgate–Lewis House was constructed by Robert C. Lambie in 1888, and was built in a late Victorian style.{{Citation needed|date=January 2026}}<ref name=":1" />
[[File:Old_map-Austin-1873-sm.jpg|thumb|"Bird's Eye View of the City of Austin", an 1873 map of Austin. Note that College Street (now 12th Street) can be seen extending from the center of the Texas State Capitol building up into Robertson Hill. College Street and Congress Avenue appear to be the two main streets of Austin, centering upon the State Capitol Building.]]The '''Southgate–Lewis House''' is a historic landmark located approximately a mile east of the [[Texas State Capitol]] in [[Austin, Texas]]. It is situated in Six Square, an [[African Americans|African American]] cultural heritage district.<ref>{{Cite web|last=The City of Austin.|title=African American Cultural and Heritage Facility.|url=https://www.austintexas.gov/aachf}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=City of Austin.|title=Guide to Six Square: Austin's African American Cultural Heritage District.|date=7 January 2022 |url=https://www.austintexas.org/austin-insider-blog/post/six-square-african-american-cultural-heritage-district/}}</ref> The Southgate–Lewis House was constructed by Robert C. Lambie in 1888, and was built in a late Victorian style<ref>{{Cite web |title=Southgate-Lewis House Historical Marker |url=https://www.hmdb.org/m.asp?m=26543 |access-date=2026-02-06 |website=www.hmdb.org |language=en}}</ref>.


The Charles M. Lewis family owned the house from 1913 to 1979. Following the death of Marguerite Mae Dee Lewis in 1970, the building was abandoned for nearly a decade and fell into disrepair. The house was scheduled for demolition after being considered a hazard to the community, but was saved and designated as a landmark.<ref name=":0" />
